You may now specify the minify: false option when pushing a script asset. Be aware that assets that are not minified will be loaded before the assets that are minified. The assumption is that the assets you can't minify are squirrely third-party critters that must be present before your code can work. In our experience uglifyjs works fine with any js code that doesn't try to sniff out its own script src attribute to find its relative location, but alas, ckeditor does that.

This is a big change: slideshows no longer contain denormalized copies of media objects. We join at page rendering time instead, which makes it much easier to tell that a media item has been moved to the trash or had its global title and description and credit changed.

YOU MUST RUN node app apostrophe:migrate OR YOU WILL WONDER WHERE ALL YOUR MEDIA WENT. Our stagecoach deployment recipes do this automatically, but in dev you'll need to do it manually.

Any templates in which you are explicitly peeking at the .items property of a slideshow must now peek at ._items instead, to be consistent with our naming policy on properties that are not part of the same mongodb document. Also consider using aposAreaFindFile to avoid most of these cases.

We also made UI improvements enabled by this change. Users can decide whether to show the title, the description and the credit for every item in the slideshow, or not.

Multiple placements of the same image with different titles are therefore no longer possible. We find this is very rare and can still be done in those rare cases by uploading two copies. However note that link titles and link URLs are still per placement.

Complete notes on this transition follow:

Titles, credits and descriptions of media will be global for that media item. There will be no per-placement editing of these fields. This is consistent with A1.5.

The decision to actually show the title, credit or description will be made by the editor at the slideshow level. That is, if you choose to show titles for a slideshow, all images in that slideshow will show their global titles. No going halfsies. This is consistent with A1.5, but better in that you're not restricted to a short list of hardcoded "variants" of the slideshow; you get to make each choice individually in a nice UI. (We'll likely later add other options in that same UI area, like slideshow interval and the existing orientation picker.)

"Link URL" and "Link Title" are still per-placement and have no global equivalent, so the "extraFields" option and the "wrench" for individual images are not going away.

Slideshows will not contain denormalized copies of media info anymore. Instead they will join on the fly with the files collection, so that they can tell if media has been moved to the trash and refuse to display it, display the media's updated title, display a replacement version of the file (soon), etc. This is consistent with A1.5. If we determine it's a performance issue we can add a more robust denormalization strategy later, with backreferences so we can figure out where the denormalized copies are and update them. There is no penalty for waiting on that.

A migration has been implemented to copy all of the appropriate information from placements to the global media objects before moving it to a backup property, legacyItems, of the media objects.
Added a progress display to the media library, by refactoring the one from slideshows. However this does not appear yet for some reason. Going to hand that over to Stuart after I push my changes

Please welcome pageLink, a lovely macro for outputting a link to a page in a consistent, feature-ful and correct fashion.

Usage:

{{ pageLink(page, { options... }) }}

Outputs a simple anchor tag pointing to a page. The anchor tag gets the apos-page-link class.

The title is correctly escaped.

If the page is unpublished, the apos-unpublished class is added to the link.

If options.url is set, it is used instead of the page URL.

If options.void is set, javascript:void(0) is used as the URL.

If options.class is set, it is applied to the anchor element.

Rich text editor fix: when hoisting block elements that have been nested under other block elements, treat widgets specially. Widgets should never become the parent of their former siblings. Instead they should be a separate element in the content stream between their former parent and their former successors, which become kids of a newly created clone of the widget's parent. New aposMerge Express local allows you to merge additional options, etc. with an object and returns a new object with all of the properties of the objects passed in. New migrations: trim title, trim slug, set sort title if missing, and convert any ObjectIDs in _id to plain strings. A2 uses plain strings for _id to simplify JSON serialization, among other reasons. Convert pages created by folks unaware of this rule by removing and reinserting them. It's an easy mistake especially when writing an importer from another CMS. When writing an importer the best way to create IDs is often to base them on the IDs in the old system, with a suitable prefix.

Support for legacy passwords hashed by Apostrophe 1.5 / Symfony 1.4 / sfDoctrineGuardPlugin. These are hashed and salted but the salt is applied differently so the regular password-hash module doesn't like them. It is simple, though, to check them directly with the crypto module. To leverage this support set the "algorithm" part of the password string to "a15sha1" (you may suffix a different algorithm if your algorithm column in sf_guard_user is not sha1, just prefix it with a15). apostropheA2ExportPlugin supports this.

This is a major commit with numerous changes.

* The default permissions mechanism has been beefed up, made more consistent, implemented for both MongoDB queries affecting many documents and ad hoc inquiries about a particular object, and generally moved a long, long way down the road. You will no longer want to set the `permissions` option to your own method in most cases. See: https://github.com/punkave/apostrophe-sandbox/wiki/Adding-people-and-groups-to-your-existing-project
* The apos.get method, and derivatives like snippets.get, now have separate `criteria` and `options` parameters. `criteria` is passed straight to MongoDB, typically in an $and with other criteria. `options` is the new home for custom options we implement ourselves, like the `published` option that accepts `1`, `0` or `any`, and also for options that affect the way results are returned, like `skip`, `limit` and `fields`. This means a significant change in all subclasses of snippets is needed. See: https://github.com/punkave/apostrophe-sandbox/wiki/BC-break-to-apos.get,-snippets.get-and-friends
* jQuery 1.10.1, with full source (our own minifier is fine for production)
* Better support for jquery.selective
Adding cursor to items already in the slideshow.

* Also updating the source of the Less middleware.

Finally found out why our deploys sometimes showed old CSS! It wasn't stagecoach's fault at all, it was the minifier. Our minifier was looking at LESS only if the CSS did not exist. So if there was an old, stale compiled CSS version of a LESS file present (as the result of deploying from a dev workstation other than that where it was tested), it would use that stale code. Now the minifier always looks for LESS first and always uses that rather than trusting what the non-minified dev environment might or might not have done already.

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:punkave/apostrophe

* Whoops, brought back snippet sorting, sorry
* apos.joinOneToOne, apos.joinOneToMany, apos.joinOneToManyReverse methods of much general utility for loading groups with people and so on
* formTypeaheadList macro begins process of making the snippet multiple select feature of the widgets useful elsewhere

* apos.get now checks permissions as part of the query, rather than performing a very expensive fetch of all pages followed by separate permissions calls.
* The new permissions scheme is similar to A1.5 permissions. If the req.user.permissions array contains 'admin' that user can fetch everything. Otherwise, if they have a req.user.groupIds property, that array is checked against the viewGroupIds and editGroupIds of pages. All users can see pages that do not have the loginRequired property. The 'published' criterion is checked for, as always, and enforced for non-admins who do not have edit privileges by way of editGroupIds.
* Actual group memberships are still coming.

* id generator is available as a method server side

* `build` nunjucks filter builds a URL, starting from a base URL and adding parameters to the query string, or to the path if an array of path-worthy properties is specified as the first argument. After the path array if any, the rest of the parameters are objects whose properties are applied to the query string or path as appropriate. The last object wins, so it is easy to override filters in a URL
* `aposPageRange` is a simple nunjucks helper that returns a suitable range of pages for the pager. This is a workaround for some nunjucks bugs, ideally this would all be in pagerMacros.html
* apos.sanitizeInteger correctly maps NaN to the default
* Basic CSS for the pager

Merge branch 'master' of github.com:punkave/apostrophe

* New enhanceDate method sets up jquery ui datepicker in a reusable way and ensures the format is always our standard format (YYYY-MM-DD).
* formatTime tolerates a null, undefined or empty time and returns it as itself. Deciding whether no time at all is acceptable is not our job here.

The browser-side method apos.formatTime accepts a standard 24-hour time as used on the backend (HH:MM:SS) and converts it to a friendlier format, as determined by options passed to the method or by apos.data.timeFormat. The latter means we can push this from the server side. This method closes the UX loop by allowing admins to edit a time they originally entered in 12-hour format without a jarring transition to 24-hour format.
Added truncate filter. This is our own implementation which is a little smarter than the one I see in the main branch of nunjucks although it has no options other than the length right now
Whoops, that was project level CSS

* Added `qs` nunjucks filter, which builds query strings from objects
* Added `allowed` option to areas, which limits the item types that will actually be displayed (see `controls` for how to limit what can be added in the editor). You can use a more restrictive `allowed` option to avoid displaying inappropriate widgets in excerpts. Note that rich text must be explicitly included in the list as `richText` or it will not be shown
* Added `aposAreaPlaintext` template helper, which returns a plaintext representation of an area. Note this is true plaintext, so you must escape it with the `e` filter to safely display it as part of HTML. Includes only item types that actually have an appropriate plaintext representation, which currently means richText only, although you can define a getPlaintext method for any item type (such as a widget). Includes a `truncate` option which limits the character count, avoiding word breaks if possible. The truncated text ends with a Unicode ellipsis character
* Added `apos.areaFindFile`, `apos.areaPlaintext` and `apos.truncatePlaintext` for direct access to the above functionality when not going through nunjucks
* Added `self.htmlToPlaintext`, part of the `aposAreaPlaintext` implementation which is likely to be useful separately
* Refactored `apos.partial` so that `apos.getNunjucksEnv` is broken out separately

* The apos object is now a standard node EventEmitter
* addDiffListener replaced with a 'diff' event posted via the event emitter
* All tasks post before and after events
* Listeners for events like task:apostrophe:migrate:before or :after can call apos.taskBusy to signify they are going to do async work after returning, and must then call apos.taskDone when the work is done

0.4.9: apostrophe command line tasks are born. And they already need a little refactoring, but that's life.

Command line task support, and the first task: apostrophe:migrate. Just call apos.task() before invoking listen() and, if it returns true, don't invoke listen(). Apostrophe takes care of the rest. The apostrophe:migrate task makes any necessary updates to the database structure. Migrations should be safe to run and you should make this task part of your deployment process. Naturally you should be backing up your site with frequency and enthusiasm.

Always hoist any widgets trapped inside another element before serializing them. This was spotted in the wild in a floated element. * Forgot to mention this important detail: please welcome the new "versions" collection. Every edit to a page object, whether via putArea or putPage, results in a new copy of that object in the "versions" collection for use in implementing rollback. The forthcoming UI for this will be specific to modules such as apostrophe-snippets and apostrophe-pages. A UI for using it with global elements is also desirable.

* Standalone areas have been removed from Apostrophe. You can still use getArea and putArea, but your slug must be of the form page-slug:areaname. Areas are always stored in the areas property of a page, the areas collection has been removed. This eliminates code paths we are not using ourselves and don't wish to leave in a half-working state. (Hey, we're in alpha.)
* putPage and putArea now take a mandatory req object as the first parameter and always call apos.permissions for you. This avoids the need for redundant permissions code. The page object is always passed to apos.permissions instead of the slug if it is available. Note that you can look at page.type to make type-specific decisions about blog posts, events, etc. (Hey, we're in alpha.)

* Options can now be passed to aposSingleton and aposArea, which ultimately reach the templates for the widgets, as well as the javascript for the widgets. aposArea's options should be grouped into properties by widget name. This is tested for singletons
* /edit-virtual-singleton implemented. Provides a singleton edit button in a pure browser side javascript context in which storage is provided by the caller (in other words, we can now have singletons in snippet forms)

* Limit option for slideshows

* apos.change('something') now triggers a full refresh of the "main content area," which is a new div wrapping everything that isn't the admin bar. This is a simple, coarse-grained, hopefully foolproof way to make sure edits you make in the admin bar are reflected in the main content area, no matter what is there - including, for instance, blog slots and map slots that could directly or indirectly use the content you just changed. apos.change still sends a jQuery event specific to its parameter as well to help dialogs such as the `manage` dialog understand that they need to update themselves, but for the main content area we have one simple refresh action.

For this to work your site must respond differently when the apos_refresh query parameter is present, sending only the contents of the data-apos-refreshable div. The pages module implements this and can be used as a reference implementation if you have pageviews on your site not rendered by `apostrophe-pages`.

The server side can now initialize the browser side code for all modules without the need for redundant browser-side code in site.js or the layout.

* apos.isUniqueError(err) no longer takes a field name, because in the case of the "_id cannot be changed" error it is not really possible to tell whether it is related to a particular field that caused the record not to be unique. The caller is responsible for making sure they know about all the relevant fields that could be leading to non-uniqueness. This issue comes up when using upsert.
* The inevitably ubiquitous apos.escapeHtml() is available.

* apos.tagsToArray() now converts to lower case (after discussion with Kerry we feel this is a feature, partly because it means mongo does the right thing).

`locals` option to easily pass in more locals to be visible in all Express and Apostrophe template rendering

API change: the `getArea` and `getPage` methods now take a req object as their first argument, and so do widget `load` functions. This enables widgets to perform permissions checks, for instance to determine whether the current user actually has permission to view a particular snippet. It also provides a context for caching during the lifetime of a single request, which is pretty much always a good idea to avoid checking the same things repeatedly on the same page.
Debugging

* Page IDs are strings, not awkward ObjectID thingummies. Easier to pass back and forth
* Pages cannot be implicitly created with putArea anymore; if you want to use pages initially create them with putPage
* The apostrophe module's views folder is always the last thing in the chain of overrides so you can extend stuff found there
* apos.slugify now accepts a separator argument, which still defaults to '-'
* The new apos.sortify method returns a string that is suitable for tolerant text searches and sorts. The string is slugified with a single space as the separator
* Autocomplete menu's z-index always beats dialogs
* apos.getRadio and apos.setRadio methods work around the horror of trying to get radio buttons to do anything with jQuery
* widgetEditor.html renamed to baseWidgetEditor.html so that modules that supply a single widget can have widgetEditor.html
MIT license, as we've always gone with

Implemented server-side load functions for item types. If your item type must load additional data not kept in the area or page collection in order to render itself, implement a load function. Load functions are asynchronous and they all run in parallel, however be aware that you are still blocking the display of the page, so you should not use a load function for anything you can't do quickly. Consider using a browser-side player function instead for anything that isn't important for SEO.

* Refactored to allow custom widgets in separate npm modules
* Refactored to just generally be less of a pain to write a widget
* Refactored to use the server side normal view rendering for previews
Version 0.3.0

Render all item views on the server. Store items as a structured mongodb array rather than storing entire areas as a single string of markup. This opens the door to full validation by the server, quick access to the first item of a particular type, and SEO-friendly rendering. This will be a bc break so in a day or two it'll go out as 0.2.0.
Fewer console.log calls
Documented requirement to inject a new pages collection

Version 0.2.0: areas with slugs like /about:main are stored as the 'main' property within the 'areas' property of an object in the 'pages' collection with the slug '/about'. getArea and putArea take care of this for you transparently. The new getPage method returns the entire page. The pages collection is new and must be supplied via options when initializing Jot. Note that there is no restriction on storing additional information in page objects via MongoDB, which allows their use for diverse purposes requiring one or more areas per "page," including blog posts, upcoming events, and traditional pages.
Removed redundant code
Style menu reflects current style at selection
Behold my badass DOM flattener https://github.com/boutell/jot/issues/10
Bulleted lists complete the bare minimum functionality for a useful RTE

0.1.14: controls option to jotArea determines which controls are shown for this particular area. Making incremental moves toward a more extensible set of controls. Added a "style" menu offering reasonable choices and removed the proof-of-concept "big" and "normal" buttons, but we still need bulleted lists. Toned down the padding of buttons to a more reasonable level. Introduced the jot-control CSS class, which is shared by menus and buttons to get the same styling.
version 0.1.13: addressed missing preformatted font
Preformatted text for code samples was missing (0.1.12)
Destroy editors properly when an area is saved or editing is cancelled. This fixes a lot of rangy exceptions thrown by timers attached to editors no longer in the DOM
Eliminated lots of webkit (Chrome) bugs by preceding and following the widgets with invisible unicode characters which are always selected at the same time
Changed arrows to Unicode word joiner character (invisible, occupies no space). SUCCESS! Chrome much happier, other browsers not negatively affected by their presence.
Brought back the arrows, currently for everyone (should be just for chrome), to see if they fix problems. Looks like it.

Fixed many, many, many bugs related to copy and paste in Chrome. Chrome does terrible things to widgets when cutting, copying and pasting them. Recognize half-busted widgets and restore them from a snapshot. (TODO: think about how to make that work across pages. The server would have to retain the snapshots for us. Awesome.)

Version 0.1.9: replaced the clumsy inline placeholder arrows with smart "Before" and "After" buttons on the widgets. Click "Before" and the text "Type Here" appears where you'd expect, preselected so you can type right over it. This is so much better. Thanks to Geoff DiMasi for jogging my brain
Documented imagemagick requirement

* First-time hint dialog box. For now the only hint explains the arrows displayed before and after rich content items in the midst of the text. For now browser side cookies are used to remember which hints you've seen.
* Refactored the modal method to jot.modal where it can be leveraged for any purpose, such as hints. Modals don't currently support stacking, so you need to hide any previous modal before opening a new one.
* Code samples correctly align left when the overall widget is centered.
* Better box size for toolbar buttons.
* Clicking on a content widget now selects the entire widget including its arrows. This makes copying and pasting widgets a lot easier and also helps emphasize that they are a single unit. In general the logic for selecting an entire widget on demand has improved a lot. Works in both Firefox and Chrome.
* Undo point timer no longer breaks the focus in modals.
* Refactored pushSelection and popSelection to jot.pushSelection and jot.popSelection and made jot.modal responsible for calling them in most situations.
* More image size fixes; also, don't trash jot-widget divs when cleaning up issues with divs related to the "large" button in Firefox
Fixed the file upload spinner so people don't get confused
Images are sized to match the sizing of their widget again, whoops
Removed console.log calls to avoid IE issues
Version bump for focus fix
Give focus to editable area as soon as edit button is clicked (it's hard to find it otherwise)
Broke jotwiki out to a separate git repository. Otherwise there are chicken and egg problems when you want to deploy it because it must require jot.
Missing dependency
Another stray dependency
Version bump to replease deployment fix
Stray dependency on oembed in the wiki app broke deployment
Markdown cleanup; inclusion of stagecoach deployment recipe for curious parties

Packaged for npm release

Permissions implemented and tested, documentation completed, getArea method added, road map migrated into the README.md file

* The demo app is now a wiki
* Completely factored out so that it can be used from another module, etc.
* Converted all internal templates to Nunjucks (but your app doesn't have to use it)
* Eliminated bootstrap dependencies

At this point all I absolutely must do is add a way to do security checks on editing operations.
The sample app is a wiki now. Typical "area" editing controls and mongo storage of areas and files will be in the box. More refactoring to come.

jot rich content editor, work in progress. Timeline: born in my jetbird project, factored out to work standalone, now reworking the sample app to be a wiki which is a lot closer to use cases I'm interested in but doesn't require me to solve all the interesting but unrelated issues of page trees before I can release something useful via npm. I also probably have to kill the bootstrap dependency and bust up the views into sample-wiki-specific stuff and stuff that needs to be usable from an app that isn't occupying a privileged position in the same folder
